femur: <entryFree id="n17913" type="main" key="fe^mur"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕmur</orth>, <itype>ŏris or ĭnis</itype> (acc. to a <case>nom.</case> ‡ femen, mentioned only by <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 701</bibl> P. and <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 10, 344</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">778</bibl>; <case>nom.</case> femus, Ap. M. 8, p. 216, 15; cf.: <foreign lang="greek">mh=ros</foreign>, femus, Gloss. Lab.; <case>dat.</case> femori; femini only <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:217" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 15, 61, § 217</bibl>; <case>abl.</case> usually femore, but femine, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:788" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 788</bibl>; <number>plur.</number> femora or femina; <case>dat.</case> feminibus, rarely femoribus), <gen>n.</gen> <etym>etym. dub.; cf. root feo of femina, etc.</etym>, <sense id="n17913.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the upper part of the thigh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the thigh.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17913.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ima spina in coxarum osse desinit, etc. ... inde femina oriuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 8, 1 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frons non percussa, non femur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:80:278" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 80, 278</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferit femur dextrum dextra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">femur caedere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:12:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 12, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:123" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 3, 123</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">feminis plangore et capitis ictu uti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 15, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:35:99" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 35, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:43:section=93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 43, § 93</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">transfixus femore et umero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:68" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 68</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:80" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 80</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nocet femori conseruisse femur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:8:26" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 8, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et corpus quaerens femorum crurumque pedumque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">teretes stipites feminis crassitudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:73:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 73, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ocius ensem eripit a femine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:788" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 788</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">galli feminibus pilosis, cruribus brevibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:9:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 9, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17913.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n17913.3" n="A" level="2"> In architecture, <hi rend="ital">the space between the grooves of a triglyph</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17913.4" n="B" level="2"> Femur bubulum, <hi rend="ital">a plant otherwise unknown</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 9, 56, § 81</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17913.5" n="C" level="2"> Esp., like lumbi, <hi rend="ital">the loins</hi>, of ancestry (Eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">de femore Jacob,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ex. 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:46:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Gen. 46, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
fenarius: <entryFree id="n17914" type="main" key="fe_na_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnārĭus</orth>, v. faenarius.</entryFree>
fendicae: <entryFree id="n17915" type="hapax" key="fendi^cae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fendĭcae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>findo</etym>, <sense id="n17915.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">entrails used as food</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hirae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, 230</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
fendo: <entryFree id="n17916" type="gloss" key="fendo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fendo</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype> <etym>v. defendo, fustis</etym>, the primitive word of the compounds defendo, offendo, infensus, and infestus; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 923</bibl> P.</entryFree>
fenebris: <entryFree id="n17917" type="main" key="fe_ne_^bris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnē^bris, fēnĕrārĭus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">fēnĕror</orth>, etc., v. faenebris, faeneror, etc.</entryFree>
fenectani: <entryFree id="n17918" type="main" key="Fenecta_ni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Fenectāni</orth> <itype>campi</itype>, <sense id="n17918.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a region in</hi> Latium, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 12, 5</bibl> Weissenb.</sense></entryFree>
fenestella: <entryFree id="n17919" type="main" key="fe^nestella"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕnestella</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>fenestra</etym>, <sense id="n17919.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small opening in the wall</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little window.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17919.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:6:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 6, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:3:3" default="NO">8, 3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:5:3" default="NO">9, 5, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17919.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fenestella</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">nom. propr.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17919.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Porta,</quote> <trans><tr>a gate in Rome</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:578" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 578</bibl></cit>; cf. Becker's Antiq. 1, p. 175.—</sense><sense id="n17919.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Masc.</hi>, L., <hi rend="ital">a Roman historian under Augustus and Tiberius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:195" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 74, § 195</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:28:4 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 28, 4 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
fenestra: <entryFree id="n17920" type="main" key="fe^nestra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕnestra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (also contr. festra, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 3, 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Fragm. p. 872</bibl> Burm.; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=91:6" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 91, 6</bibl> Müll.), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>root <foreign lang="greek">*f*a*n</foreign>, in <foreign lang="greek">fai/nw, fanero/s</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n17920.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an opening in the wall to admit the light</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a window</hi> (orig. closed by two wooden shutters or by curtains, and not till the empire by sheets of mica, lapis specularis; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Dict. of Antiq. p. 520 sq.): neque fenestra, nisi clatrata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fenestras indere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 1, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fenestrarum angustias quod reprehendis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bifores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:3:5" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 3, 3, 5</bibl></cit>: juncta, <hi rend="ital">closed</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 25, 1</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">patulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:752" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 752</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reticulatae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:7:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se plena per insertas fundebat luna fenestras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 152</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diversas percurrens luna fenestras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:3:31" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 3, 31</bibl></cit> Burm. ad loc.: <cit><quote lang="la">fenestram in arca facies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 6, 16</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n17920.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n17920.2" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A loop-hole</hi> for arrows, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">(in turri) fenestras ad tormenta mittenda, in struendo reliquerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n17920.3" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The recess of a window</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">concludere in fenestram firmiter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 1, 44</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17920.4" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A breach</hi> made by besiegers in a wall: <cit><quote lang="la">excisa trabe firma cavavit Robora et ingentem lato dedit ore fenestram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:482" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 482</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17920.5" n="4" level="3"> Of the senses, <hi rend="ital">windows</hi> for intelligence: <cit><quote lang="la">ut facile intelligi possit, animum et videre et audire, non eas partes, quae quasi fenestrae sint animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:20:46" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 20, 46</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n17920.6" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, transf., of <hi rend="ital">holes</hi> through the tips of the ears: <cit><quote lang="la">natus ad Euphraten, molles quod in aure fenestrae Arguerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:104" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 104</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17920.7" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an entrance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admission</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opportunity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inlet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">occasion</hi><pb n="735" /> <cb n="FERA" />  (very seldom): <cit><quote lang="la">hui quantam fenestram ad nequitiam patefeceris!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 72</bibl></cit>: si hanc fenestram aperueritis, nihil aliud agi sinetis, Tiber. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:28" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
fenestro: <entryFree id="n17921" type="main" key="fe^nestro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕnestro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>fenestra</etym>, <sense id="n17921.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to furnish with openings</hi> or <hi rend="ital">windows</hi> (rare; not in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n17921.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">media oculorum cornua fenestravit pupilla,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 55, § 148</bibl></cit>. —In <hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">valvata ac fenestrata triclinia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=29" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 29</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">singulae partes turris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 19 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>—* </sense><sense id="n17921.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">oportuit hominum pectora fenestrata et aperta esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3 praef" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3 praef.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
fenestrula: <entryFree id="n17922" type="hapax" key="fe^nestru^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕnestrŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n17922.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little window</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
feneus: <entryFree id="n17923" type="main" key="fe_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnĕus</orth>, v. faeneus.</entryFree>
fenicularius: <entryFree id="n17924" type="main" key="Fe_ni^cu^la_rius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Fēnĭcŭlārius</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Faen-</orth>) <orth extent="full" lang="la">campus</orth>, <sense id="n17924.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Fennelfield</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a place in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis (so called because abounding in fennel); as a descriptive designation for <hi rend="ital">Spain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
feniculum: <entryFree id="n17925" type="main" key="fe_ni^cu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnĭcŭlum</orth>, v. faeniculum.</entryFree>
fenisex: <entryFree id="n17926" type="main" key="fe_ni^sex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnĭsex</orth>, v. faenisex.</entryFree>
fenisicia: <entryFree id="n17927" type="main" key="fe_ni^si^ci^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnĭsĭcĭa</orth>, v. faenisicia.</entryFree>
fenni: <entryFree id="n17928" type="main" key="Fenni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Fenni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n17928.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tribe in the north and northeastern parts of Europe</hi>, not of the Germani, called <foreign lang="greek">*fi/nnoi</foreign> by Ptolemy, probably <hi rend="ital">the Finns</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 46</bibl>; v. Orell. ad h. l.</sense></entryFree>
fenum: <entryFree id="n17929" type="main" key="fe_num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnum</orth>, v. faenum.</entryFree>
fenus: <entryFree id="n17930" type="main" key="fe_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fēnus</orth>, v. faenus.</entryFree>
fera: <entryFree id="n17931" type="main" key="fe^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. ferus.</entryFree>
feracitas: <entryFree id="n17932" type="main" key="fe^ra_ci^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrācĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ferax</etym>, <sense id="n17932.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fruitfulness</hi> (post-Aug. and very rare), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
feraciter: <entryFree id="n17933" type="main" key="fe^ra_ci^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrācĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <sense id="n17933.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fruitfully;</hi> v. ferax <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
feralis: <entryFree id="n17934" type="main" key="fe_ra_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fērālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>fero, from the carrying of the dead in funeral procession; cf. ferculum; cf. also Fest., Varr., Ov. ll. c. infra and v. Corss. Ausspr. 1, 467</etym>, <sense id="n17934.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the dead</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to corpses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">funereal</hi> (as an <pos>adj.</pos> only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">tu tamen exstincto feralia munera ferto,</quote> <trans><tr>offerings to the dead</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:3:81" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 3, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:616" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 616</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cupressus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 216</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:13:21" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 13, 21</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ferale decus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the cypress</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:535" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 535</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vittae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:103" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reliquiae,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the ashes of the dead</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferali carmine bubo Visa queri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:462" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 462</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Enyo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 120</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17934.1" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the festival of the dead</hi> (celebrated annually in the month of February): <cit><quote lang="la">tunc, cum ferales praeteriere dies,</quote> <trans><tr>the days of the festival of the dead</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:34" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:486" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 486</bibl></cit>: mensis, i. e. <hi rend="ital">February</hi>, Col. <usg type="style">poet.</usg> 10, 191. —</sense><sense id="n17934.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrālĭa</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the general festival of the dead kept on the</hi> 17<hi rend="ital">th</hi> or 21<hi rend="ital">st of February</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the feast of All Souls</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">inferiae, justa, pompa, exsequiae, funus): hanc, quia justa ferunt, dixere Fĕralia lucem: Ultima placandis Manibus illa dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:569" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 569</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">feralia ab inferis et ferendo, quod ferunt tum epulas ad sepulcrum, quibus jus ibi parentare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 13</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">feralium diem ait Varro a ferendis in sepulcra epulis dici,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: feralia diis Manibus sacrata festa, a ferendis epulis, vel a feriendis pecudibus appellata, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=85" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 85</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">eodem die video Caesarem a Corfinio profectum esse, id est, Feralibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 14, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diem finiri placuit Feralia, quae proxime fuissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 7, 3</bibl></cit> Drak. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n17934.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">deadly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fatal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dangerous</hi> = funestus: <cit><quote lang="la">tune, Licha, dixit, feralia dona tulisti?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:214" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 214</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:2:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 2, 260</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:374" default="NO" valid="yes">374</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 5, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">papilio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:374" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 374</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">papilio pestifer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 19, 21, § 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Idus Mart. ferales Caesari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:237" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 26, 65, § 237</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenebrae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2,31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aula, a term applied to the abode of the great African serpent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:216" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 216</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">feralior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pacat.</author> Pan. Theod. 46, 4</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: nefas feralissimum, Salv. Gub. Dei, 1, p. 23.—In <hi rend="ital">neutr. adv.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferale gemiscere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Rapt. Pros. 3, 130</bibl></cit>.— <itype>Hence</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">fērālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">fatally</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut leo feraliter invadit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Fulg.</author> Myth. 3, 1 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
feratrina: <entryFree id="n17935" type="gloss" key="feratrina"><orth extent="full" lang="la">feratrina</orth>, a word in <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 63, 26</bibl>, compared as to its form with moletrina, but without an explanation of its meaning.</entryFree>
ferax: <entryFree id="n17936" type="main" key="fe^rax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrax</orth>, <itype>ācis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>fero</etym>, <sense id="n17936.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fruit-bearing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fruitful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fertile</hi> (rare but class.). </sense><sense id="n17936.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> —<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: terrae, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1098" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1098</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:44:section=104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 44, § 104</bibl></cit>; cf.: feracissimosque agros possidere, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 4, 6</bibl>: Sardinia,<cb n="FERE" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:31:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 31, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Algidus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 4, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aegyptus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:18" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plantae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 79</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17936.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abounding in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">productive of</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">Iberia, venenorum ferax,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:22" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Peparethos nitidae olivae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:470" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 470</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra Cereris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 2, 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra arborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:17:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 17, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acini musti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 24, 29, § 100</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17936.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra ferax Cereris multoque feracior uvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illa (terra) ferax oleo est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:222" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 222</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17936.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">making fruitful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">venti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Nov. 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17936.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">rich</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fertile</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fruitful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullus feracior in philosophia locus est, nec uberior, quam de officiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil est feracius ingeniis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:15:48" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 15, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prolisque novae feraci Lege marita,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Carm. Sec. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferax saeculum bonis artibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:15:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 15, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sitne feracius et uberius non ad laudem modo, sed ad pecuniam principi, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:43:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pan. 43, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, * <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrācĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">fruitfully</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">velut ab stirpibus laetius feraciusque renata urbs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ferbui: <entryFree id="n17937" type="main" key="ferbui"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ferbui</orth>, v. ferveo <sense id="n17937.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
ferctum: <entryFree id="n17938" type="main" key="ferctum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ferctum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. fertum.</entryFree>
ferculum: <entryFree id="n17939" type="main" key="fercu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fercŭlum</orth> (or uncontr. <orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrĭcŭlum</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 90:15" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 90, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:122:3 al" default="NO">122, 3 al.</bibl>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>fero</etym>, <sense id="n17939.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that on which any thing is carried</hi> or <hi rend="ital">borne.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17939.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A frame</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a barrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">litter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bier</hi> for carrying the spoils, the images of the gods, etc., in public processions: <cit><quote lang="la">spolia ducis hostium caesi suspensa fabricato ad id apte ferculo gerens in Capitolium ascendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:10:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 10, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:37" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Caesar) tensam et ferculum Circensi pompa, etc. (recepit),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:76" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caes. 76</bibl></cit>: ut pomparum ferculis similes esse videamur, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:36:131" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 36, 131</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17939.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A dish</hi> on which food is served; and hence <hi rend="ital">a dish</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mess of food</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a course</hi> (perh. not anteAug.; cf.: epulum, daps, commissatio; <cit><quote lang="la">merenda, prandium, etc.): ubi multa de magna superessent fercula cena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 6, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cenae fercula nostrae Malim convivis quam placuisse cocis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:82" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 82</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:74" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 10, 47, § 136</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:94" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:184" default="NO">7, 184</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:64" default="NO">11, 64</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
fere: <entryFree id="n17940" type="main" key="fe^re_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">fermē</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrĕ</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epigr. 10, 5, 5</bibl>), <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. dhar-, dhar-ami, to bear, support; Gr. root, <foreign lang="greek">qra</foreign>-, in <foreign lang="greek">qrh=nus</foreign>, stool, <foreign lang="greek">qro/nos</foreign>, seat; Lat. firmus; cf.: forma, forum. Ferme is perh. a sup. form for ferime, v. R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Lat. Part. p. 6 sq.</bibl> Erroneously, Varr.: ferme dicitur quod nunc fere: utrumque dictum a ferendo, quod id quod fertur est in motu atque adventat, L. L. 7, § 92 Müll.</etym>, <sense id="n17940.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">approximately</hi>, <hi rend="ital">closely</hi>, in two senses. </sense><sense id="n17940.1" n="I" level="1"> With the idea of <hi rend="ital">approach</hi> predominant, <hi rend="ital">nearly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">almost</hi>, <hi rend="ital">well-nigh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">within a little</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for the most part</hi>, <hi rend="ital">about</hi> (esp. with words of number, quantity, multitude; cf.: plerumque, vulgo). </sense><sense id="n17940.2" n="a" level="4"> Form fere: <cit><quote lang="la">fere sexennis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abhinc menses decem fere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 24</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">fere abhinc annos quindecim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fere in diebus paucis, quibus haec acta sunt, Chrysis vicina haec moritur,</quote> <trans><tr>soon</tr>, <tr>only a few days after</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 1, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quinta fere hora,</quote> <trans><tr>about the fifth hour</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hora fere tertia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:20:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 14, 20, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tertia fere vigilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:23:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 23, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sexcentos fere annos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sexto decimo fere anno,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anno fere ante, quam consul est declaratus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anno fere centesimo et quadragesimo post mortem Numae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 15</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">anno trecentesimo et quinquagesimo fere post Romam conditam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">decem fere annis post primos consules,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 32</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">also: decessit fere post annum quartum quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Arist. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Arist. 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meus fere aequalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:48:179" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 48, 179</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsa Peloponnesus fere tota in mari est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:4:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 4, 8</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">totius fere Galliae legati ad Caesarem gratulatum convenerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:30:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 30, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totis fere a fronte et ab sinistra parte nudatis castris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 23, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rerum omnium fere modus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 18</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quam fere omnium constans et moderata ratio vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:16:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 16, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex omnibus fere partibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in reliquis fere rebus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 13, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes fere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 10, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 25, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 20, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Arist. 2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Arist. 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Chabr. 3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Chabr. 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:60:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 60, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:87" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 87</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and in the order fere omnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 13, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 23, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus disputationis fuit extremum fere de immortalitate animorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:4:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 4, 14</bibl></cit>; cf.: Phalereus ille Demetrius ultimus est fere ex Atticis. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:80" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 80</bibl>: cum <cb n="FERE" /> fere e regione castris castra poneret, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:35:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 35, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 12, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus fere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:1:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 1, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">semper fere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">satis fere diximus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:18:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 18, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum fere,</quote> <trans><tr>almost only</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lycurgus eadem vidit fere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec fere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 34</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc fere ab reliquis differunt, quod,</quote> <trans><tr>in this chiefly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 18, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec fere dicere habui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:39:93" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 39, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec erant fere, quae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 12, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 30</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:16:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 16, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:54:182" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 54, 182</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 32, 102</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exposui fere non philosophorum judicia, sed, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:16:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 16, 42</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">sic fere componendum, quomodo pronuntiandum erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:138" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 138</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fere eodem pacto, quo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et fere apparet, quid in invidiam, etc. ... dicendum sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:12:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 12, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17940.3" n="b" level="4"> Form ferme: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc factum est ferme abhinc biennium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">abhinc annos ferme L.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:90" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 90 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam ferme ante annos DCCCCL. floruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:5:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intra XII. ferme annos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duodequadragesimo ferme anno, ex quo regnare coeperat Tarquinius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mille ferme delecti propugnatores onerariis imponuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 10</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pars ferme dimidia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 42, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a quo (flumine) aberat mons ferme milia viginti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 48:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 48, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">in tumulo quatuor ferme milia distante ab castris regiis consedit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abest ab Carthagine quindecim milia ferme passuum locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferme eadem omnia, quae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ferme cunctos proceres cum honore nominavisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi quidem aetas acta est ferme,</quote> <trans><tr>for the most part</tr>, <tr>about</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 38</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n17940.4" n="II" level="1"> With the idea of nearness or closeness predominant, <hi rend="ital">quite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">entirely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17940.5" n="a" level="4"> Form fere: <cit><quote lang="la">domum revortor maestus atque animo fere conturbato,</quote> <trans><tr>quite distracted</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod statuas quoque videmus ornatu fere militari,</quote> <trans><tr>quite military</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:18:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 18, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paria esse fere peccata,</quote> <trans><tr>quite equal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi nobis, qui id aetatis sumus, evigilatum fere est, tamen, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>entirely</tr>, <tr>sufficiently</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum circa hanc fere consultationem disceptatio omnis verteretur,</quote> <trans><tr>just on this debated point</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 7, 1</bibl></cit>: jamque fere, <hi rend="ital">just now</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 217, 11</bibl>; and ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 114</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 286 and 580 ed. Vahl.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 135</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 327</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">835</bibl>; cf.: jam fere, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 355, 17</bibl> (Trag. v. 201 ed. Vahl.); and: jam ... fere, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=46" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 46</bibl> Müll. (Ann. v. 447 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">sermo qui tum fere multis erat in ore,</quote> <trans><tr>just then</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:1:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 1, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17940.6" n="b" level="4"> Form ferme: circumvenire video ferme injuria, <hi rend="ital">altogether wrong</hi>, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=92" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 92</bibl> Müll. (R<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:Trag. Fragm. p. 12" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Fragm. p. 12</bibl>); cf.: ferme aderant ratibus, <hi rend="ital">just</hi>, Enn. ib. § 23 Müll. (Ann. v. 602 ed. Vahl.); so, quod ferme dirum in tempus cecidere Latinae, Cic. Poët. Div. 1, 11, 18; and: <cit><quote lang="la">sed eum constabat virum esse ferme bonum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:2:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferme ut quisque rem accurat suam, Sic ei procedunt post principia denique,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 1, 4</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ferme ut pueri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam ferme moriens me vocat,</quote> <trans><tr>just dying</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 5, 49</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17940.7" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n17940.8" n="1" level="3"> With negatives, <hi rend="ital">scarcely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hardly.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17940.9" n="a" level="4"> (= vix, non facile.) Form fere: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil aut non fere multum differre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:40:150" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 40, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemo fere saltat sobrius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:25:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 25, 116</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil fere intelligit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:3:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non fere labitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod non fere ante auctumnum Elaver vado transiri solet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:35:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 35, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duo spondei non fere jungi patiuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:101" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in se dicere non est fere nisi scurrarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:82" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 3, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">denique ex bellica victoria non fere quemquam est invidia civium consecuta,</quote> <trans><tr>hardly any one</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:23:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 23, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rationem sententiae suae non fere reddere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 17, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec adhuc fere inveni, qui, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 6, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quod non fere contingit, nisi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:20:72" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 20, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec rei fere sane amplius quicquam fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in qua (disputatione) nihil fere, quod magno opere ad rationes omnium rerum pertineret, praetermissum puto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 8 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: tum est Cato locutus; <cit><quote lang="la">quo erat nemo fere senior temporibus illis, nemo prudentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:1:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixit, hunc ne in convivio quidem ullo fere interfuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque ullum fere totius hiemis tempus sine sollicitudine Caesaris intercessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:53:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 53, 5</bibl></cit>: neque enim <pb n="736" /> <cb n="FERE" /> fere iam est ullus dies occupatus, ut nihil, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:7:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 7, 27</bibl>.—With a neg. interrog.: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quid fere undique placet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 2, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17940.10" n="b" level="4"> Form ferme: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc non ferme sine magnis principum vitiis evenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 45 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:38:111" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 38, 111</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod non ferme decernitur, nisi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 9, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:25:9" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 25, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluptatibus erant inferiores, nec pecuniis ferme superiores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 34 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">nec ferme res antiqua alia est nobilior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facio, quod manifesto moechi haud ferme solent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 40</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 1, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud ferme,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 7, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:28:14" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 28, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut eo nihil ferme quisquam addere posset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:43:161" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 43, 161</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia nemo ferme huc sine damno devortitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 1, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non ferme facilius aliquid tenere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 45, 69</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17940.11" n="2" level="3"> Of time (in the usual course of things; opp. to sometimes, now and then), <hi rend="ital">in general</hi>, <hi rend="ital">generally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">usually</hi>, <hi rend="ital">commonly.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17940.12" n="a" level="4"> Form fere: <cit><quote lang="la">Fit fere, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 10</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">jam hoc fere sic fieri solere accepimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Imp. Pomp. 9, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod fere solet fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:29:46" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 29, 46</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">also: ut fere fit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam fere maxima pars morem hunc homines habent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod fere libenter homines id, quod volunt, credunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:18:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 18, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificio circumdato silva (ut sunt fere domicilia Gallorum, etc.),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 30, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ruri fere se continebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam fere non difficile est invenire, quid, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 18, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eum fere est voluntas nostra propensior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:20:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 20, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic omnia nimia in contraria fere convertuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod in illis singuli fuissent fere, qui, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nominatim fere referri, quid, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:33:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 33, 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nigra fere terra,</quote> <trans><tr>commonly black</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 203</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui timet his adversa, fere miratur eodem quo cupiens pacto,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 9</bibl></cit>.—Strengthened by <hi rend="ital">plerumque</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plerique</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic solebamus fere Plerumque eam operiri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 1, 2, 39</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">corresp. to plerumque: fortuna eos plerumque efficit caecos, quos complexa est: itaque efferuntur fere fastidio et contumacia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:15:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 15, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adducto fere vultu, plerumque tacitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:68" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non sunt vitiosiores, quam fere plerique, qui avari avaros ... reprehendunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:30:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 30, 73</bibl></cit>.—Opp. <hi rend="ital">raro</hi>, <hi rend="ital">interdum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">saepe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fere praedicta aetas laeto solo truncoque tres materias, raro quatuor desiderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:17:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 17, 5</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">fereque id in capillo fit, rarius in barba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse Circenses ex amicorum fere libertinorumque cenaculis spectabat, interdum e pulvinari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:15" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in consulatu pedibus fere, extra consulatum saepe adaperta sella per publicum incessit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 53</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17940.13" n="b" level="4"> Form ferme: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ferme evenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam ferme apud Numidas in omnibus proeliis magis pedes quam arma tuta sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 74 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inculta ferme vestiuntur virgultis vepribusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intacta invidia media sunt: ad summa ferme tendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 45, 35</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">mobilis et varia est ferme natura malorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:236" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 236</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ceterum parva quoque (ut ferme principia omnia),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ferme ad nova imperia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae antea dictatorum et consulum ferme fuerant beneficia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:30:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 30, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nocte ferme proficiscebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 13, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ferentarius: <entryFree id="n17941" type="main" key="fe^renta_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrentārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Sanscr. dhvar-, laedere, destruere, Corss. Krit. Beitr. p. 178</etym>, <sense id="n17941.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sort of light troops who fought with missile weapons</hi> (syn. rorarii). </sense><sense id="n17941.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">ferentarii equites hi dicti, qui ea habebant arma, quae ferrentur, ut jaculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=57" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 57</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf. id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 520, 11 sq.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">erant inter pedites, qui dicebantur funditores et ferentarii, qui praecipue in cornibus locabantur et a quibus pugnandi sumebatur exordium: sed hi et velocissimi et exercitatissimi legebantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 1, 20</bibl></cit>; cf. also Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=85:7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 85, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:93:14" default="NO">93, 14</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and 369, 5 Müll.: postquam eo ventum est, unde a ferentariis proelium committi posset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 60:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 60, 2</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sing. collect.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferentarius gravisque miles, illi telis adsultantes, hi conserto gradu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 35</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n17941.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">one who is active</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ready</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illum tibi Ferentarium esse amicum inventum intellego,</quote> <trans><tr>a friend ready to assist</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 55</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ferentina: <entryFree id="n17942" type="main" key="Fe^renti_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīna Aqua</orth>, <sense id="n17942.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small river in the neighborhood of</hi> Alba Longa, <hi rend="ital">near the</hi> <cb n="FERI" /> <hi rend="ital">modern Marino</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at the source of which there was a grove sacred to the deity</hi> Ferentina (perh. the same as Diana); <cit><quote lang="la">here the Latini used to hold their general assemblies: ad caput aquae Ferentinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:51:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 51, 9</bibl></cit>; for which: ad caput Ferentinae, Cinc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=241:12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 241, 12</bibl> Müll. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.;</hi> and: <cit><quote lang="la">ad caput Ferentinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 38</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ad lucum Ferentinae conveniant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 50</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:52:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 52, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:25:5" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 25, 5</bibl>. (This place is different from Ferentinum, the city of the Hernici; see the foll. art.).</sense></entryFree>
ferentinum: <entryFree id="n17943" type="main" key="Fe^renti_num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <sense id="n17943.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A small solitary town of the Hernici</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Via Latina</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Anagnia and Frusino</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Ferentino</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:51:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 51, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 9, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:2" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 2</bibl>. —Used to signify a little solitary countrytown, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17943.1" n="B" level="2"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n17943.2" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Ferentinum;</hi> only <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Ferentinum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Ferentines</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:395" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 395</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n17943.3" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīnas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">Ferentine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:9:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 9, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">populus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:43:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 43, 23</bibl></cit>; also: Ferentinatis populus, Titin. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 629</bibl> P.—In <hi rend="ital">plur. subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīnātes</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Ferentinum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Ferentines</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:42:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 42, 5</bibl>; Inscr. Orell 1011. —</sense><sense id="n17943.4" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīnum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentium</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a small town in Etruria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the birthplace of the Emperor Otho</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Ferento</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 8, § 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 53</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">called municipium Ferentium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 50</bibl></cit> Orell. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.;</hi> and: <cit><quote lang="la">municipium Ferenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 2, 7, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n17943.5" n="B" level="2"> Deriv.: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrentīnen-sis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Ferentinum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Ferentine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Colonia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:de Colon. p. 131" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> de Colon. p. 131</bibl></cit> Goes.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3507</bibl>.—In the form FERENTIENSIS, Inscr. in Ann. dell' Inscr. Archeol. 1, p. 176.</sense></entryFree>
ferentum: <entryFree id="n17944" type="main" key="Ferentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ferentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. Forentum.</entryFree>
fereola: <entryFree id="n17945" type="hapax" key="fereo^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fereŏla vītis</orth>, <sense id="n17945.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sort of vine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:2:28" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 2, 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
feretrius: <entryFree id="n17946" type="main" key="Fe^re_tri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Fĕrētrĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ferio; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">in the foll.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 10, 45; acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 10, 6</bibl>, from fero</etym>, <sense id="n17946.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname of Jupiter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the subduer of enemies</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and to whom the</hi> spolia opima <hi rend="ital">were consequently offered.</hi> </sense><sense id="n17946.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc spolia in templo tria condita causa Feretri, Omine quod certo dux ferit ense ducem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 10, 45; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:ib. 1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1</bibl> sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 10, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 33</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 4, 20 sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:20:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 20, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:1:11" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 1, 11</bibl>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=92:1" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 92, 1</bibl> Müll. al.— * </sense><sense id="n17946.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">of Amor</hi>: opima apposui senex Amori arma Feretrio, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1518,001:page=2442" default="NO"><author>Ter. Maur.</author> p. 2442</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
feretrum: <entryFree id="n17947" type="greek" key="fe^re_^trum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrē^trum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">fe/retron</foreign>, <sense id="n17947.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a litter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bier</hi>, etc., for carrying trophies in a triumphal procession, the bodies of the dead, their effigies, etc.; pure Lat. ferculum (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">quis opima volenti Dona Jovi portet ferĕtro suspensa cruento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:5:168" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 5, 168</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:17:630" default="NO">17, 630</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jamque rogum quassasque faces ferĕtrumque parabant,</quote> <trans><tr>bier</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:508" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 508</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:747" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 747</bibl> (ferētro); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:222" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 222</bibl> (ferētro); 11, 64 (ferētrum); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:11" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:567" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 567</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyneg. 488</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4370 al.</bibl>; cf.: ubi lectus mortui fertur, dicebant feretrum nostri, Graeci <foreign lang="greek">fe/retron</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=166" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 166</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
feriae: <entryFree id="n17948" type="main" key="fe_ri^ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fērĭae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype> (in the <number>sing.</number>: FERIA a feriendis victimis vocata, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=85:12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 85, 12</bibl> Müll.), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>for fes-iae, same root with festus</etym>, <sense id="n17948.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">days of rest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">holidays</hi>, <hi rend="ital">festivals</hi> (syn. justitium), a great number of which, both private and public, were kept by the Romans; the latter being either stativae, <hi rend="ital">fixed</hi>, regularly recurring on certain days; or conceptivae, <hi rend="ital">movable</hi>, settled every year anew; or imperativae, <hi rend="ital">temporary</hi>, ordained by the consuls on account of some particular occurrence; <cit><quote lang="la">or, lastly, the Nundinae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 13</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:12:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 12, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 22, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 1, 3</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">feriae Domini,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Levit. 23, 2</bibl></cit>: feriae denicales, Latinae, novendiales, privatae, etc., v. sub h. vv.—</sense><sense id="n17948.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">rest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peace</hi>, <hi rend="ital">leisure</hi>: indutiae sunt belli feriae, Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:25:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 25, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praestare Hesperiae longas ferias,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>peace</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:5:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 5, 37</bibl></cit>.—Comically: venter gutturque resident esuriales ferias, <hi rend="ital">keep hunger-holidays</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">fast</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 1, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tuas possidebit mulier faxo ferias,</quote> <trans><tr>shall fill</tr>, <tr>amuse your leisure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 37</bibl></cit>.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">sine ullis feriis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>without rest</tr>, <tr>incessantly</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit>; cf.: feriis caret necessitas, <hi rend="ital">necessity has</hi> <cb n="FERI" /> <hi rend="ital">no law</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 6, 7</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">feria,</quote> <trans><tr>a week-day</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Jejun. 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
feriaticus: <entryFree id="n17949" type="main" key="fe_ri^a_ti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fērĭātĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ferior</etym>, <sense id="n17949.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">free from labor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">holiday</hi>-: <cit><quote lang="la">dies,</quote> <trans><tr>a holiday</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:12:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 12, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
feriatus: <entryFree id="n17950" type="main" key="fe_ri^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fērĭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from ferior.</entryFree>
fericulus: <entryFree id="n17951" type="hapax" key="fe^ri^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrĭcŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n17951.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [ferus], <hi rend="ital">somewhat wild</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 39, 4</bibl></cit> dub.</sense></entryFree>
ferinus: <entryFree id="n17952" type="main" key="fe^ri_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n17952.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to wild animals</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; <cit><quote lang="la">not in Cic., for Inv. 1, 2, 2, is to be read victu fero): vultus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:523" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 523</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:12:55" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 5, 12, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:675" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 7, 675</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caro,</quote> <trans><tr>venison</tr>, <tr>game</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 18:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 18, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:89:7" default="NO" valid="yes">89, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:161" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 161</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lac,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:571" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 571</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestis,</quote> <trans><tr>of the skins of wild beasts</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1418" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1418</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluptates,</quote> <trans><tr>brutal sensuality</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 2 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>— <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <trans><tr>low</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 26, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">15, 3</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n17952.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the flesh of wild animals</hi>, <hi rend="ital">game</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 215</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:569" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 569</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pomum a ceteris distans sapore quodam ferinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 4, 9, § 43</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ferio: <entryFree id="n17953" type="main" key="fe^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">fĕrĭo</orth>, <itype>īre</itype> (archaic FERINVNT for feriunt; acc. to Fest. s. v. nequinunt, p. 162, 24 Müll.; <sense id="n17953.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">part. fut.</hi> feriturus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 7, 498</bibl>. The <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> forms are supplied by percutio, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:55:section=98" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, 55, § 98</bibl> Müll.), <itype>4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>perh. Sanscr. dhūr-, injure, destroy; Lat. ferus, ferox; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">qh/r</foreign>; Aeol. <foreign lang="greek">fh/r</foreign>; cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">qou/rios</foreign>, impetuous, <foreign lang="greek">qorei=n</foreign>, to leap; and Lat. furere, furia, etc.</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to strike</hi>, <hi rend="ital">smite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">knock</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cut</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thrust</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hit</hi> (class.; syn.: icio, percutio, verbero, vapulo, pulso, tundo, pavio). </sense><sense id="n17953.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n17953.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">fores,</quote> <trans><tr>to knock</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 2, 63</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">parietem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:24:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 24, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">murum arietibus,</quote> <trans><tr>to batter</tr>, <tr>shake</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 76:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 76, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugiles adversarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: jacere telum, voluntatis est; <cit><quote lang="la">ferire quem nolueris, fortunae,</quote> <trans><tr>to strike</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:17:64" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 17, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">partem corporis sibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:441" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 441</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frontem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">femur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:123" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 123</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pectora solito plangore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:554" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 554</bibl></cit>;
